Entry.1: Enlisted in D.A.C. at Sydney and transferred to D.A.P. .
Entry.2: Left for Melbourne in D.A.P. M.T.
Entry.3: Left for Egypt on A.40. S.S. Ceramic.
Entry.6: A.A.S.C. Australian Army Service Corps (M.T.) 3000 all told.
Entry.7: on board. Recd Card and cigarettes from Mrs Tunbridge and cigar from Lieut Parry Okeden.
Entry.8: Arrived at Albany. Saw Submarine AE 2.
Entry.9:
Sailed from Albany with the Convoy. Ships in Convoy

Ulysees - Flag

Suevic

Ceramic

Persic

Themestocles

P. Macquarie

Borda

Willochra N.Z.

Berrima

Kt of the Garter N.Z.

Vestalalia G. 

Verdola N.Z.

Cannstadt G.

Ayrshire A 33

German Prize G.

 " " G.

 " " G.

 " " G.

Was put under open arrest for being late for Parade through watching ships leaving. Admonished.
Entry.11: Plenty of fun. Concert at night.
Entry.15: -Fleet parted company. Ceramic, Persic & Suevic to proceed to Aden, remainder passed 28 miles W of Cocos Islands to go to Columbo. First mail taken off. Steaming all lights out.
Entry.16: - Passed Minikoi, on Starbd side at noon. First land since leaving.
Entry.17: - Passed Socotra, on our Port side.
Entry.18: - Second innoculation. Vaccination did not take owing to being recently done.
Entry.19: - Arrived at Aden. A bare Barren Rock, our first death occured here.
Entry.20: - Lying near us Mail Steamer Morea, (Homeward bound) who passed us in Forenoon and the Auxilary Cruiser "Empress of Russia" & a number of other ships.
Entry.21:
- Funeral on Shore. Bumboats doing great business. 
No one
 allowed on shore.
Entry.22: - Convoy arrived at 9 am. We all sailed at 6 pm.
Entry.23:
- Entered Red Sea during night. Buried one man at Sea.

Empress of Russia auxillary cruiser passed us going South.
Entry.26:
- Started to go through Suez Canal at 10 am. All along both sides were Territorials and Gurkas and Indian Soldiers. The trenches were plainly visible. Patrols could be seen in the distance out over the Desert. At 3 pm we anchored at north end of Bitter Lakes near by was a big French Battleship, anchored at the mouth

of the Canal was H.M.S. Ocean, since lost at the Dardanelles.
Entry.27: - Started again. Passed Ismalia. Saw some Queenslanders & their guns. During passage of Canal we saw H.M. Ships Ocean, Cleo, Swiftsure & Minerva. (Bob Hollands first ship) and any number of small tugs, etc & the H.M.S Hardinge. Arrived at Port Said at 5 pm, one man died. Body was landed. Ship was coaled. At Port Said was the Hospital Ship "KYRRA" & an Italian Cruiser.
Entry.28: - Left Port Said 8 am. One man died & was buried ashore.
Entry.29: -Arrived at Alexandria. U.S.A. Cruiser Tennessee was in harbour.
Entry.30: -15 & 16 Battalions disembarked and Supply Section D.S.C.
Entry.31: - Ammunition Section & all officers to disembark. Col Tunbridge went to Cairo and wired that both Units can proceed to England Complete.
Entry.32: - Left for England. Was recalled just on leaving the Harbour. Appointed Ships Signaller along with Corporal Warrington.
Entry.33: - This morning at 5 am was on duty on bridge when Ceramic nearly hit another ship swinging with the wind.
Entry.34: - Disembarked with Supply Section of D.S.C. & proceeded to Cairo by special train. Several fights took place as a result of bad beer.
Entry.35: - Arrived at Abbassia and marched to the Camp, passing through the new barracks en route. The
Entry.36: Manchesters (T) are quartered there. Got a sleep on tables in the mess rooms as it was 2.30 am when we arrived. E Lancs. Div at Cairo.
Entry.37:
- Our Section took over ammunition at El Gusha magazine at rear of citadel and foot of Mokattam

Hills. The Pyramid of Gizeh & others are plainly seen. We go to work in G.S. Waggons of the 10 A.S.C. (10 a.a.s.c. ) who take the ammunition from the store to the train where we load it
Entry.38: visited pyramids & sphinx & went to Mena to see Maxbut he was out on a day bivouac.
Entry.39:
- I was going on guard at 6 pm & was waiting for my pay, Bob Wilson (since killed) called my name & I turned around & the stone he flicked at me struck me in my right glass, breaking it and some of the glass went into my eye. I was in great pain & went to the Hospital tent to get treated. Pain still continued, so was relieved

I went to the
Entry.40:
Aus Gen Hosp& was admitted. Whilst there Gen Maxwell visited the Hospital.

TBO



Mother

Aug 19th

off Guard to go to Heliopolis Palace Hospital, 1st Aus Gen Hospital. A piece of Glass¼" inch long was taken from under the lower lid. I was then sent to bed, & had drops in my eyes every four hours until Sunday forenoon. General Maxwell visited the Hospital & spoke to me about the glasses. Had 60 Pt taken out of Purse.

23rd Feb - Discharged from Hospital. Fresh Glasses prescribed.

March

3rd March.- Was put on Guard on the Ammunition train.

4th- Received new glasses.

6th - Left for Alexandria with 400 tons of Ammun.

Arrived at Alexandria & was camped in No 14 Shed in docks near French gates.

7th March.- Hospital Ship Guildford Castle came alongside with Wounded Indians. I afterwards went out with Wald & a man of the L.F. to see them & had nice talks with some of them.

Plenty to do now with guards at the shed & loading the transports with their quota of ammunition. It turned out to be for the Dardanelles.

When rest of Coy came from Cairo we went to Camp A.

28th. - Was admitted to Hospital tent with bad ears (noises) & heavy spasmodic coughing. Lieut U.E. Parry Okeden ordered me to parade sick & like the rotter he is punished me for being 
slack
, although my ears were bad, & I could not here the orders. He did not wait for doctors verdict but punished me first.

Some French Artillery and their horses camped here (Camp A, Gabbari).

for the night.

30th Mar. - 29th Division (Regulars) started to arrive.(100 day out)

Munster Fus

Border Regt

Dublin Fus

S.W. Borderers

Iniskilling Fus

K.O.S. Borderers

Royal Fusiliers

Worcesters

R. Irish

Essex

R. Scots

R. Welsh Fusiliers

April 5th - Sentpresents to Mother & Flo.

April 4th. - Saw Max on Derflenjer, Advanced Guard of 10 men left on "City of Benares".

17th April. - Driver Tanner 1st A.A.S.C. drowned whilst swimming horses.

18th April Sund. - Visited Catacombs & Pompeys Pillar. Tombs are 2000 years of age & are not very lively being all bones & graves.

19th. - Given permission to wear crossed flags.

21st April. - We were swimming near the tram terminus at Mex when Driver Tanners body was washed ashore.

Apr 22nd. - Buried Tanner in Military Cemetery with 
full
 honours. The whole Company turned out.

April 25th. - Australians & English troops landed on Gallipoli.

28th. - Plenty of wounded started to come in. Wrote Mother & Flo.

1st May. - East Lancs Div Began to Embark.

9th May. - Cleaner Williams accidently killed with tram.

10th May. - Williams Buried with 12 other men in trench.

11th May. - Posted Presents & wrote letter & P.C. to Mother & Flo.

12th. - Bob Wilson Killed at Anzac. He was our First Death at the Front. A Decent chap.
Entry.44: - Orders came tonight at 9 pm to Embark for ----
Entry.45:
- Sent Kitbags to Base and Embarked on Cunard liner S.S. Franconia, there were a lot of new Japanese Bombs on board & four of their

(Franconia since sunk in Mediterranean.)

guns. A lot of English details also on board.
Entry.46: - Sailed at 4 pm for Dardanelles. Had life belt & boat drill several times.
Entry.47:
- Had Holy Communion. Arrived at Cape Helles. The Turks were giving the Beach camp a warm time with big shell. One ship was shelling Achi Baba & some French Men of War were shelling the Asiatic side. It was a great sight.

Shrapnel could be seen bursting all about the Place. Occassional Bursts of Rifle fire could also be heard. "Lizzie" was not there.
Entry.48:
- Gen Bridges Died. Left Cape Helles for Anzac. Passed Ark Royal with captive Balloon. Off Anzac was H.M.S. "Queen" shelling Kuchuk Anaparta, with her 6" guns. She afterwards got two 12" shells in and made a splash on the paddocks. The 6"

went all round the Minaret of a Mosque (Painted white) but did not hit it. It was good Practice. We landed at 6 pm & got some shells as a welcome but none came near us. Lindsay & Anderson were sent back & never landed. 
Turks attempted a abuseof Red Crescent flag
.
Entry.49:
- Went to Indian battery & B. Depot (over Suicide Point). Had day off to make our dugouts, as tents are non est. No flat ground to pitch them. There was a night attack at the trenches & we had our first hearing of heavy rifle fire. There is a N.Z. 4.5" Howitzer near my dugout & she speaks loud & deep

19th MayWednesday. - This evening I was one of the escort for Ammunition to the 1st & 2nd Brigade trenches. We had 57 mules, as no carts can conveniently work up the ridge. All the way allong the stray bullets which missed the trenches are dropping in the bushes around us. After passing through the Gap on Hell's spit we came in the region of strays. A check came & we halted by some carts with a beastly smell. They

turned out to be carts full of dead men. It gave me a shock as I did not know where the burial ground was & it was midnight, with no moon. This trip we went to
Entry.50: Brig right up to about 50 yds from the trenches. The noise was terrific, one incessant rattle & roar. We went back to the beach, & loaded up again & found only 16 mules, the others had sneaked off to bed. We got away to the second Brigade & a mistake brought several mules back with their ammunition. The third trip had a mule shot.
Entry.51:
- The beach had a heavy shelling. An attack was thought likely so all hands had to stand to arms until 
10 pm.
 Turks attemped abuse of Red Crescent flag. Heavy fire started at 8 pm but died off.
Entry.52:
- Turkish 
General
 Colonel came in under white Flag which he showed at Gaba Tepe. He was escorted to Anzac Blindfolded. I met him on his return to Gaba Tepe. Col Cox wounded. He was carried past us. I am told he only went into the trenches yesterday. We made a magazine for the Japanese bombs

on the track leading to the First Brigade trenches. The bombs were carried from the beach by infantry fatigues as the mules are too rough for them. The men in the trenches say the bombs are something terrific, one Turk having been blown 20 feet in 
the air spinning
 around.
Entry.53:
(May) - Finished Bomb Shelter. There were several casualties among men going up & down 
to the trenches.
Entry.54: - Truce for burying dead. Estimated that 3000 Turks were buried. Everything went off satisfactorily.
Entry.55: - H.M.S. Triumph was torpedoed at 12.24 pm & was on her beam ends at 12.35 & finally disappeared at 12.55. Excitement was great. Some destroyers came rushing up from Cape Helles. I was boiling my billy when a man called out She's torpedoed. I looked up & saw her heel. The destroyers rushing from Helles & all around us was a great sight. About 50 only were lost. She was firing up to the last.
Entry.56:
- An engineer was going up the path at Hells spit & a shell burst right in front of him and blew him to bits. The next burst over the beach & the shrapnel went over the heads of us who were waiting for water & struck the water line of the barge. Only only wounded one sailor although about 30 men were on the barge dressing & bathing. Four destroyers with their decks full of troops got a lively reception from the Turks Artillery. On one destroyer about 8 shells burst

right across her killing 14 & wounding over 40.

Received letters from Mother, Flo & Mrs Rogers. Sent P.C. to Mother & Flo.

The man who was hit on the path was in a hell of a mess. Stomach & thighs in one mess, both arms smashed, fingers off & his chest full of holes. He was carrying a bag of mail & the letters went up in a cloud.
Entry.57:
- Burried Lyddite & common shell near the Naval 6" Howitzer, several shell fell near

us, but owing to the formation of the ground, the pellets could not reach us. The Capt was there, but cleared out when the shells started to come. Some men were wounded on our right by these shells.

When a shell comes on the beach we first hear a faint report & then the shell comes whistling over & 
crack
 usually followed by a shout of "Stretcher bearer". The bearers are wonderfully plucky. I have seen them at 5 oclock in the morning getting men off Hells spit.

and about a dozen shells bursting in 5 minutes.
Entry.58: - Letters from Flo, also Paperletter from J. Sent field P.C. to Mother and Flo.
Entry.59:
- Last night the Turks exploded a mine at Quinns Post. Some of them, I believe actually got into the support trenches. They were repulsed with 1500 to 2000 casualties. The Howitzers were going strong.

Potts & McIntosh were carring bombs & Potts got wounded in the foot.
Entry.61: - Submarine chase all the destroyers were going in circles etc & the transports & Hospital Ship went to Imbros. As it was dinner time I had a fine view of the proceedings.
Entry.63: - Reported to N.Z.E. recommended for Distinction for Blowing up Bomb proof shelter.
Entry.64: - A three funnel cruiser fired 16 broadsides of 5 - 6" into some place near Anafarta.
Entry.65: - More men killed with Shrapnel. The beach is a warm place at times. Ammunition loading fatigue until 1 am. Very heavy firing at Cape Helles. Attack on Quinns Post
Entry.66:
pm to 1 am.
 Could see flashes of guns & hear Jap bombs bursting.
Entry.67: - Reported Spy captured8 Aus. Engineer signalling to Enemy.
Entry.68:
- Went sick, strained back, off duty 
for 3 days.
Entry.69: - Peninsular Press says troops at Helles advd centre 500 yds, & that Submarine E 11 sunk 1 Gunboat, Transports, Supply ships & ammunition ships.
Entry.72: - Was woke up at 5 am by two 4 funnel cruises firing, one near Cape Suvla & the other near Gaba Tepe. They finished about 7 am. Received Paper from Flo. One of our Aeroplanes dropped 3 bombs on the Turks trenches. Wrote to Flo.
Entry.73:
- Gave Flos letter to Officer to censor.

With Light Horse. Had Ten rounds at a loophole in Turk trenches with a periscope rifle.

Went with Bowie to position above the beach slightly to right of Quinns Post & could see Turks & our trenches.
Entry.74: - Monitor shelled position near Gaba Tepe.
Entry.75: - Saw Capt Bean Officer correspondent to Commonwealth.
Entry.76: - Went to 3rd Battalion trenches & saw Max Tassens and was surprised to see me. We had a yarn, but he was on telephone duty so I went into the firing line & had a look at the trenches through a periscope. Gave censor a letter for Flo.
Entry.77:
- Letter & Paper from Mrs Rogers & letter redirected from England & 3 from Flo. Heavy firing still proceeding from Cape Helles. Gaba Tepe shelled for about 30th time. Went to left flank to get 18 pd cartriges cases, got into L.H. trenches. Had 30 rounds (with a periscope rifle) of loophole in Turks trench. Made several hits on edge of hole.

Gave censor letter for Mother & card for Flo.
News from Helles that French had taken the Haricot Redoubt.

June 2
1
Entry.78:
- Heavy firing from Helles. Monitor shelled Gaba Tepe & aeroplane
dropped 3 bombs on it, one 5 ft from gun emplacement & one 10 ft
 directed its fire.
Entry.80: (City of Glasgow) R.F.A. 52 Lowland Division landed and went straight to their position.
Entry.81: : continued - Beach had a heavy shelling today. About 3 pm a shell caught 16, of whom 4 died in a short time. About 5.30 pm a shell dropped 6 feet in front of my dug out & killed L/C Walsh & wounded driver Fraser with 16 bullets. The bag for the day was 29.
Entry.82:
- Was shifting dirty cartridges near the Hospital when a shell from somewhere east of Gaba Tepe fell right into the Rifle & Equipment part of the Australian Ordnance. The shelling lasted for over an hour, two fell in the Indian Ordnance & wounded the Sergt & set the

ammunition on fire. Another made a big hole in a water tank. A stack of boxes behind us was knocked over & one man had a slight cut on the head. Hacket taken to hospital with ptomaine poisoning from Bully Beef.
Entry.83: - Letter from Mother & 2 from Flo. Reported sick and ordered to Base with Catarrhal deafness. Went on board H.S. Gascon & was later transferred to "Prince Abbas". The rope fouled the propeller & we sailed at 5.30 pm. Arrived at Lemnos about 11.30 pm.
Entry.84: - The bay at Lemnos (Mudros) was crowded with battleships & other vessels. Went ashore to Hospital.
Entry.85: - Saw doctor. Diagnosis Chronic Otitis Media & perforated drum.
Entry.86:
- Left Lemnos on H.S. 
Dunluce Castle.
Entry.87: - Arrive Alexandria 6.30 am. Disembarked after Dinner & was taken to Deaconess Hospital
Entry.89: - Wrote to Mother, Flo, J & Sergt Logan.
Entry.90: - Wrote to Mrs Rogers, Aunt Harriet & Aunt Polly.
Entry.92: - Operation on Left Antrum of Highnose for Empyema of same. Wrote to Flo & Mother.
Entry.93: - Operation Repeated. It is done with cocaine, but the Trocar can be felt piercing something at side of nose.
Entry.95:
Repeat operation.Today I saw a mans ear opened from the back. The operation was for mastoditis & had started bleeding immediately after the man had been put to bed, so it was opened

up again to tie the 
vein
artery. It to¾ of an hour.
Entry.96: - Wrote to Commonwealth Savings Bank - went to confession.
Entry.100: - Wrote to to Bowie & sent him a paper,
Entry.105: - Wrote to O.C. Base. Band played.
Entry.106: - Wrote to Anglo Egyptian Bank. Priest gave me prayer Book.
Entry.108: - Wrote to Mother, Flo. Received Letter from Mr Hinde.
Entry.110: - Wrote to Mr Hinde. Letter from Jim. Wrote to Jim.
Entry.111: - Rec'd letter & Card from Anglo Egyptian Bank.
Entry.113: - Goods on a/c 24½. Wrote to Aunt Polly.
Entry.114: - Wrote to Mother, Flo & O.C. D.A.P. at Anzac.
Entry.118: - Letter from Commonwealth Savings Bank. I looked after a Sergt Frost from 3pm to 8 pm and he died at 10pm.
Entry.120: - Wrote to Mother. Letter from Jim.
Entry.125: - Discharged from Hospital & attnd X Ray Room of 19th General Hospital.
Entry.126: - Had first leave since May 9th. Went to Kursaal.
Entry.127: Continued - Met some of of Drivers & Cleaners from Anzac & heard of a lot of Casualties.
Entry.128: - 3 Letters from Flo, wrote to Mother.
Entry.130: - Wrote to Flo & to Savings bank to acknowledge receipt of Money. P.C. From Ruby.
Entry.131: - Sent P.C. to Mother, Flo, Joe & Paddy.
Entry.132: - 2 Letters from Flo, wrote to Flo. Sent P.C. to her & Ruby.
Entry.133: - Wrote to Mother & Army P.O. Anzac. P.C. for Flo.
Entry.134: - Two letters from Flo, one from J. Wrote to Flo. 2 P.C.'s for Joe, 3 for Flo.
Entry.135: - P.C. to Mother & Flo. Sent Broch to Mother and to Flo. Pin to Joe.
Entry.137: - Letter from Bowie& Bias. Completed 1 years service.
Entry.138:
- 2 letters from Mother, 1 from J & from M Hinde. Took sacks of papers to be burned. 
Wrote to Bowie
 Wrote to Bowie, sent Pictures to Flo & Mother, P.C. to Mother, Flo & Mrs Rogers. Papers to Jim & Bowie.
Entry.139: - Went to Orwa-el-Waska (Medical Division of 19th General Hospital Egyptian) schools.
Entry.140:
- P.C. to Mother, Flo & Jim. Received 18 letters. Mother 6, J 5,Flo 5, Mrs Rogers 1. One from West Aus.

Entry.142: - Wrote to Flo & Mother. Sent small tin type photos.
Entry.143: - Went Sick. Work in Ward Kitchen knocks me out. Am on medicine & Light Duty, going on nightPolice. Wrote to Mrs Rogers & Miss Higgs who wrote from Northam W.A. to enquire about Driver Twomey.
Entry.145:
- Saw C.S.M. OLoughlan.

23 Thurs September - Sent Flo 11 P.C. & 13 letters to date. Sent Mother 7 PO.C. & 11 letters to date. News of Jim being wounded
Entry.147: - Two letters from Mother. Saw S.M. OLoughlin at Camp. Bulgaria & Greece Mobilising.
Entry.148: - P.C. to Mother & Flo. Was having a snooze after night duty when I was woke up to go to Mustapha to rejoin my unit. Met Jenkins & Stobbs. Went to Mustapha camp. Am to to go Lemnos.
Entry.150: Innoculation for Cholera. Saw Watts, Ampleton, Barrel.
Entry.151:
- Saw Aurist, said Phlegm could be put right by doing something to nose
after the War
. Sent parcel of 75 guns & German Helmets etc to Mother & Flo. P.C. to Mother & Flo.
Entry.152:
- To get job at base.

Money rec'd 
Deferred14- 3- 0
Bank 20- 6- 0
Pay 
 16- 6- 6
50-15- 6
Entry.153: - Pictures to Janis, Mrs Roper, Mother, Flo, Janie. P.C. to Janis. Warned for draft overseas tomorrow. Sent parcel of Badges.
Entry.154:
- Embarked for Lemnos on S.S. Manitou.

Roll call under difficulties. Motors, niggers & ships machinery all making a noise at once. This is the ship which was chased by a Turkish Torpedo boat & about 50 men drowned through accident of boats. Cleared breackwater at 7.45 pm.
Entry.155: - Had alarm stations. French four funnelled cruiser passed us at dusk, also steamer at dark & one in afternoon.
Entry.156: - There is a mixed crowd on this boat. English, Irish, Scotch, Welsh, Indian, New Zealand and Australian & every arm of each contingent. Also R.N. R.M.L.I. & R.N.D. . Boat drill twice a day.
Entry.157: - Off Crete at daybreak. About 9.45pm a Destroyer came & asked our names (4 ships in Company) also speed & time of arrival at Lemnos. She said she would report the probable time of our arrival. Since then she has been steaming a zig zag course in front of us. I gave a little assistance on bridge.
Entry.158: - Arr Lemnos 2.30 am. Mauritania is in front of harbour. Ship with French troops alongside. Was called to the bridge to help read signals from destroyer last night. Went alongside Z21 at 1 pm Lake Manitoba.
Entry.159: - Had holdall & shaving tackle taken out of my Haversack.
Entry.160:
- Raining slightly, some Artillery & mails left for Anzac. Storm with wind & 
lightning at 7.30pm
Entry.161: - Lots of mail being unloaded. Wrote to Mother & Flo.
Entry.162: - Disembarked & went to Base Camp. Hellish muddle, no dinner. Biscuits for Tea. Marched waded through Lake about 4 miles out of track.
Entry.163:
- Medical Exam B2, will have to go before board. Went on Guard 6pm. A cold 
windy night. Wrote to Base.
Entry.164: - Came off Guard 6 pm. Still cold & windy.
Entry.167: - Went sick. Cold in head. Paining at back & sore.
Entry.168:
- Wrote to Mother, Flo & J. Board decision B.I.X.

(Lines of Communication.)
Entry.169: - Left for Anzac. Off Achi Baba at 8.30. arr Anzac 10pm.
Entry.170:
- Reported for Duty. Put in Bomb Factory after a few
Polite
 remarks from C.O. a/c Sickness. Anzac is much altered from when I last saw it.
Entry.171: - Went to 3 F.A. Bde re transfer.
Entry.172: - O.C. said be would agree to transfer if Battery or Brigade O.C. would. Took the application & answer to
Entry.174:
- Beach had a few shells. Cruisers shelled the gun behind

GabaTepe & Olive Groves.

Wrote to O.C.
Entry.175: Battn about Jim & O.S. Mudros for letter.
Entry.176: - Wind & sea rough. Wrote to Mother & Flo.
Entry.177:
- Transferred to 3rd B.A.C. Struck off strength of D.A.P. from today. P.C. to Mother & Flo.

No 2256
Entry.180:
- Went to Lone Pine Artillery Observing Station as cook for party of 10.



Tues.2nd November - Letters from Flo (with Photo of Cissie & Ruby & herself), Mrs Rogers & Aunt Harriet.
Entry.181: - Went in Lone Pine trenches & had a look at the Turks trenches.
Entry.182: - Posted letter to Flo, & Mrs Rogers, P.C. to Aunt Harriet.
Entry.184: & Aug 7th, Syd Mail 14 July. Queenslander from Mrs Rogers.
Entry.185: - Shells from Turks fell in Gully, also bomb at night.
Entry.186: - 2splinters of shell (1 Turk) & 1 from our 6" Lyddite fell within 3 feet of Cookhouse today. Some heavy 8.2 burst on ridge 50 yards away & one piece went over my head.
Entry.188: - 2 Letters from Mother, 1from Cairo (Change of address) Mother says she has heard of Jim being wounded. Bombs again last night and several shells at crest of Ridge behind Kitchen.
Entry.189: - Posted letter to Mother. F.S. Post Card to Mother, Flo, J, Aunt Polly, Mrs Rogers
Entry.190:
- Receive 2 ozs tobacco & 50 cigarettes from Overseas Club. Reply P.C's were addressed to
W Danham Esq, York. W.A.
Mr J Hayes c/o P.O. Box 57, Meekathara W.Aus.
K was here today.
Entry.191: - Letter from Flo. Base Re Jim & Redirected from U.E. Parry-Okeden (Mongrel). No news of where Jim is up to
Entry.192: Wrote to Flo & P.C. to Flo. Sent the P.C's in answer to people who gave tobacco & cigarettes in West Aus.
Entry.193: - On the Carpet for neglect of Duty in not drawing fresh meat. Sentence suspended for two weeks. Went sick. Knocked out. Possibly be sent away for ear trouble & knocked up.
Entry.194:
- Sent away sick. Ears & done up. SentBias drill book Back by Post.

Yesterday
Entry.195: a Taube flew over the Lone Pine. The Anti Aircraft gun put one shell just under her as she was coming back. The plane did not wait for a second shot but cleared toward Chanak in a hurry.
Entry.196: - Templeton was at Hospitalhit on head withpiece of shell. 3rd Field Amb, says tinitis & debility. Sent to 1st Aus Clearing Hospital, & then on board Hospital ship "Somali". Went to bed.
Entry.199:
- Landed & came to Cairo by Hosp Train. 
Admitted
 to No 2 A.G.H. Gezireh . PC to mother. Rec'd Package of cigarettes, matches, soap, towel, toothbrush. Post card, Paper & Envelopes from British Red Cross.
Entry.200:
- Wrote to Mother, Flo, O.C. B.A.C. Bias.
Got comb, Shaving soap, lollies, chocolate & Hdkf from Red Cross.
Entry.201: - Examined by doctor. Ears, nose & throat & eyes to be treated. Sat letter to Base.
Entry.202:
- Wrote to Mother, Flo, J. & P.C. to Mrs Rogers.

December
Entry.203: Tues. - Had eyes tested. Saw Rudder. P. who is invalided.
Entry.205: Wed - Went to Cairo toorder glasses. I am to have Wasserman test.
Entry.206: - Went to Cairo to order glasses.
Entry.208: - P.C. to Mother, J. Aunts Harriet & Polly, 2 to Flo. Med Board exam. L.O.C. Colonel did not read all the case sheets. Pay 10/-.
Entry.209: - Letter from Base re mail. Bought Telescope & G.F. Watch (£sd 7-10-0) cash£10 (special).
